newsitem.title: USA: Flight attendant tobacco trial adjourns to Tuesday.
newsitem.headline: Flight attendant tobacco trial adjourns to Tuesday.

text.p: The $5 billion secondhand smoke trial underway in a Miami courtroom began a short adjournment Thursday after a pulmonologist consulted by the lead plaintiff testified about the dangers of smoking.
Dade County Circuit Judge Robert Kaye said there would be no testimony on Friday or Monday. Attorneys will return to the courthouse on Tuesday.

During his testimony, Dr. David Burns, an author of surgeon general's reports on cigarette smoking, told the court that federal scientists had been under pressure from tobacco companies to be conservative in their investigations of links between secondhand tobacco smoke and disease.

In the case, Norma Broin et al vs Philip Morris Cos Inc et al, flight attendants are suing major tobacco companies for a variety of illnesses they claim were caused by breathing secondhand cigarette smoke aboard U.S. passenger jets.
The trial is in its second week of testimony. It is the first class action suit and the first secondhand smoke suit against big tobacco to make it to trial.
